headline: Amazon's AWS CEO chides staff for slow product rollouts
summary: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) -Amazon Web Services' top executive admonished staff on Thursday for what he called slow product rollouts by the cloud computing provider at its premier Reinvent customer event in December, according to a transcript of a meeting reviewed by Reuters.  The Amazon unit typically announces its most ambitious new products and services at the annual conference in Las Vegas.  Last year, for instance, AWS showed off its Nova chatbot, pitting it against OpenAI and other artificial intelligence rivals.

headline: India proposes tweaks to foreign investment rules for exports in possible win for Amazon
summary: NEW DELHI (Reuters) -India's government has drafted a proposal to ease foreign investment rules to allow e-commerce companies like Amazon to buy products directly from Indian sellers and then sell them to overseas customers, a document showed.  India currently prohibits foreign e-commerce companies from selling goods directly to consumers either at home or abroad, allowing them only to operate a marketplace to connect buyers and sellers for a fee.  The policy has been a sore point between New Delhi and Washington for years, and Amazon has been lobbying the Indian government to ease the rules in the case of exports, Reuters has reported.

raw.headline: India proposes tweaks to foreign investment rules for exports in possible win for Amazon
raw.summary: NEW DELHI (Reuters) -India's government has drafted a proposal to ease foreign investment rules to allow e-commerce companies like Amazon to buy products directly from Indian sellers and then sell them to overseas customers, a document showed.  India currently prohibits foreign e-commerce companies from selling goods directly to consumers either at home or abroad, allowing them only to operate a marketplace to connect buyers and sellers for a fee.  The policy has been a sore point between New Delhi and Washington for years, and Amazon has been lobbying the Indian government to ease the rules in the case of exports, Reuters has reported.

headline: Amazon Reaches $2.5 Billion Settlement With the FTC Over Prime Case
summary: Amazon.com  has reached a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission over allegations that the e-commerce giant tricked customers into signing up for Prime accounts.  Amazon  has agreed to pay $2.5 billion to settle the lawsuit that was filed by the FTC in June 2023, according to court filings.  The lawsuit stated that Amazon used “deceptive” user-interface designs to unwillingly convince consumers into enrolling in renewing Prime subscriptions.

raw.headline: Amazon Reaches $2.5 Billion Settlement With the FTC Over Prime Case
raw.summary: Amazon.com  has reached a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission over allegations that the e-commerce giant tricked customers into signing up for Prime accounts.  Amazon  has agreed to pay $2.5 billion to settle the lawsuit that was filed by the FTC in June 2023, according to court filings.  The lawsuit stated that Amazon used “deceptive” user-interface designs to unwillingly convince consumers into enrolling in renewing Prime subscriptions.

raw.summary: The agreement requires the e-commerce giant to give money back to customers and change its subscription practices.

headline: Amazon to pay $2.5 billion to settle FTC allegations it duped customers into enrolling in Prime
summary: Amazon has reached a historic $2.5 billion settlement with the Federal Trade Commission, which said the online retail giant tricked customers into signing up for its Prime memberships and made it difficult for them to cancel after doing so.  The Seattle company will pay $1 billion in civil penalties — the largest fine in FTC history, and $1.5 billion will be paid to consumers who were unintentionally enrolled in Prime, or were deterred from canceling their subscriptions, the agency said Thursday.  Eligible Prime customers include those who may have signed up for a membership via the company's “Single Page Checkout" between June 23, 2019 to June 23, 2025.

raw.headline: Amazon to pay $2.5 billion to settle FTC allegations it duped customers into enrolling in Prime
raw.summary: Amazon has reached a historic $2.5 billion settlement with the Federal Trade Commission, which said the online retail giant tricked customers into signing up for its Prime memberships and made it difficult for them to cancel after doing so.  The Seattle company will pay $1 billion in civil penalties — the largest fine in FTC history, and $1.5 billion will be paid to consumers who were unintentionally enrolled in Prime, or were deterred from canceling their subscriptions, the agency said Thursday.  Eligible Prime customers include those who may have signed up for a membership via the company's “Single Page Checkout" between June 23, 2019 to June 23, 2025.

headline: Amazon to pay $2.5 billion to settle Prime deception allegations
summary: (Reuters) -Amazon.com will pay $2.5 billion in fines and payments to Prime subscribers to settle a Federal Trade Commission case alleging the retail juggernaut signed users up for the subscription without their consent, the FTC said on Thursday.  Of that, $1.5 billion will go into a fund to repay eligible Prime subscribers and Amazon will not admit wrongdoing as part of the settlement, the FTC said.  Shares of Amazon were nearly unchanged after the news.

raw.headline: Amazon to pay $2.5 billion to settle Prime deception allegations
raw.summary: (Reuters) -Amazon.com will pay $2.5 billion in fines and payments to Prime subscribers to settle a Federal Trade Commission case alleging the retail juggernaut signed users up for the subscription without their consent, the FTC said on Thursday.  Of that, $1.5 billion will go into a fund to repay eligible Prime subscribers and Amazon will not admit wrongdoing as part of the settlement, the FTC said.  Shares of Amazon were nearly unchanged after the news.

headline: Amazon's grocery ambitions stumble in Britain
summary: LONDON (Reuters) -When Amazon opened its first grocery store outside the United States in 2021, its choice of a site in west London for a cashier-free store was seen as the start of a major assault on Britain’s $290 billion food market.  That store closed in 2023 and this week the group said it planned to shut its remaining 19 Amazon Fresh stores - a failure that highlights the brutal economics of UK food retail, and how one of the most powerful retailers in the world may still be feeling its way on how to compete globally in groceries.  Amazon, which also runs Amazon Fresh stores in the United States as well as the upmarket Whole Foods Market chain, never confirmed UK store targets, but 2021 media reports suggested plans for over 260 Fresh outlets by end-2024.

raw.headline: Amazon's grocery ambitions stumble in Britain
raw.summary: LONDON (Reuters) -When Amazon opened its first grocery store outside the United States in 2021, its choice of a site in west London for a cashier-free store was seen as the start of a major assault on Britain’s $290 billion food market. Amazon, which also runs Amazon Fresh stores in the United States as well as the upmarket Whole Foods Market chain, never confirmed UK store targets, but 2021 media reports suggested plans for over 260 Fresh outlets by end-2024.
